Key Arguments: The bill creates a distinction between two classes of citizens, giving excessive power to politicians, journalists, and educators while limiting regular citizens' voices.
Punitive fines will lead to an overly restrictive environment for digital service providers, stifling free speech.
The dynamic nature of knowledge makes it difficult to accurately differentiate between true and false information.
The bill's focus on 'misleading' or 'deceptive' information erodes freedom of speech and stifles necessary discussions.
Delegating legislative power to private entities raises constitutional concerns and undermines democracy.
The bill could harm independent media and promote biased coverage by exempting government-authorized publications.
Notable Quotes: It is a complete betrayal of trust and transparency surrounding freedom of and is a direct violation of our democratic values.
By implementing such a one-size-fits-all approach, the bill fails to appreciate the need for a nuanced and balanced approach when addressing misinformation.
Delegation to non-governmental entities undermines the fundamental principles upon which our democracy is built.
